sen.j: 裏千家（うらせんけ）は、茶道流派の一つ。
sen.e: Urasenke is one of various schools of the tea ceremony.
Urasenke is one of various schools of tea ceremony.
Urasenke is one of various schools of tea ceremony.

sen.j: 特に、表千家・武者小路千家と並び三千家の一つである。
sen.e: Specifically, it is one of the san-Senke schools (three Senke schools), the other two being Omote Senke and Mushanokoji Senke schools.
Specifically, it is one of the san-Senke schools (three Senke schools), the other two being Omote Senke and Mushanokoji Senke schools.
Specifically, it is one of the san-Senke schools (three Senke schools), the other two being Omote Senke and Mushanokoji Senke schools.

sen.j: 茶道諸流派中最大の流派で、茶道人口の過半数は裏千家門下であるとみられる。
sen.e: It is the largest school among various schools of the tea ceremony, with its pupils considered to count for majority of whole population who enjoy the tea ceremony in Japan.
It is the largest among the various schools of tea ceremony, and has the majority of students who enjoy studying tea ceremony in Japan.
It is the largest among the various schools of tea ceremony, and has the majority of students who enjoy studying tea ceremony in Japan.

sen.j: 「裏千家」の語は、家元とその家族らで構成される宗家を指すことも、財団法人裏千家今日庵などの法人組織を指すことも、弟子・門下生を含む流派組織を指すこともある。
sen.e: The word "Urasenke" refers either to Soke (legitimate family of originator house) composed of the head of the school and his family, or to such legal entity as the foundation Urasenke-Konnichi-an, or to the school itself as an organization including disciples and descendants.

The word "Urasenke" refers either to Soke (the legitimate family of the original house) composed of the head of the school and his family, or to such a legal entity as the foundation Urasenke-Konnichi-an, or the school itself as an organization including its disciples and descendants.

The word "Urasenke" refers either to Soke (the legitimate family of the original house) composed of the head of the school and his family, or to such a legal entity as the foundation Urasenke-Konnichi-an, or the school itself as an organization including its disciples and descendants.

sen.j: 宗家は京都市上京区小川通寺之内上にあり、表千家宗家と隣接している。
sen.e: Soke's residence is located at Ogawadori, Teranouchi-agaru, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, adjoining the residence of Omote Senke.
Soke's residence is located at Ogawadori, Teranouchi-agaru, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, adjoining the residence of Omote Senke.
Soke's residence is located at Ogawadori, Teranouchi-agaru, Kamigyo-ku, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, adjoining the residence of Omote Senke.

sen.j: その茶室・今日庵（こんにちあん）は裏千家の代名詞でもある。
sen.e: Name of its tea arbour, Konnichi-an, is now synonimous with the Urasenke school.
The name of its tea arbour, Konnichi-an, is now synonimous with the Urasenke school.
The name of its tea-ceremony house, Konnichi-an, is now synonymous with the Urasenke school.
sen.cmt: 茶室＝tea-ceremony house としました。

sen.j: 裏千家の名称は、表千家（不審菴）に対し、今日庵が通りからみて裏にある意。
sen.e: This school is named Urasenke (literally, backside Sen family) after its arbour Konnichi-an which is situated on the back side of Omote Senke's arbour Fushin-an.
This school is named Urasenke (literally, backside Sen family) after its arbour Konnichi-an which is situated on the back side of Omote Senke's arbour Fushin-an.
This school is named Urasenke (literally, backside Sen family) after its arbour Konnichi-an which is situated on the back side of Omote Senke's tea-ceremony house, Fushin-an.
sen.cmt: 茶室＝tea-ceremony house としました。

sen.j: 特徴
sen.e: Features
Features
Features

sen.j: 三千家の点前作法は基本的によく似通っているが、心得が無くてもわかる比較的目立った違いをいくつか挙げる。
sen.e: Basically, temae-saho (serving manners) of each school of Sansenke (three Senke schools) resembles each other, but followings are some differences among them which can be noted even by nonprofessional persons.
Basically, temae-saho (serving manners) of each of the three Sansenke schools are similar, but following are some differences that can be noticed even by nonprofessionals.
Basically, temae-saho (serving manners) of each of the three Sansenke schools are similar, but following are some differences that can be noticed even by non-professionals.
sen.cmt: スペースあるいはハイフンの脱落。 “nonprofessionals”=>”non-professionals” OR “non professionals.”

sen.j: 裏千家は薄茶をよく泡立てる。
sen.e: It is the method of Urasenke school to whisk generously the weakly flavored powdered green tea to drink.
One is the Urasenke school method of generously whisking the weak flavored powdered green tea.
sen.cmt: revised word order, etc. for clarity
sen.e: One is the Urasenke school method of generously whisking the weakly flavored powdered green tea.

sen.j: 表千家では泡が全面を覆うような点て方をしない。
sen.e: Omote-senke school does not whisk the tea so much as to cover the surface with foam.
The Omote-senke school does not whisk the tea as much to cause the surface to be covered with foam.
sen.cmt: revised word order, etc. for clarity
sen.e: The Omote-senke school does not whisk the tea as much to cause the surface to be covered with foam.

sen.j: 裏千家の茶筅は普通想像されるような白竹のものである。
sen.e: Chasen (a bamboo tea whisk) used by Urasenke school is made from shiratake (white bamboo), as commonly assumed.
The chasen, (a bamboo tea whisk) commonly used by the Urasenke school, is made from shiratake (white bamboo).
The chasen, (a bamboo tea whisk) commonly used by the Urasenke school, is made from shiratake (white bamboo).

sen.j: 表千家では煤竹を、武者小路千家では黒竹を用いる。
sen.e: Omote-senke school uses chasen made from susudake (soot-colored bamboo), while Mushanokoji-Senke school uses chasen made from kurochiku (block bamboo.)
The Omote-senke school uses a chasen made from susudake (soot-colored bamboo), while the Mushanokoji-Senke school uses a chasen made from kurochiku (block bamboo.)
The Omote-senke school uses a chasen made from susudake (soot-colored bamboo), while the Mushanokoji-Senke school uses a chasen made from kurochiku (block bamboo.)

sen.j: 裏千家の女性の帛紗（ふくさ）は緋を基本とするが柄ものなどもある。
sen.e: According to Urasenke school, fukusa (small silk wrapper) to be used by women in a tea ceremony is basically scarlet-colored plain cloth, but patterned cloth may also be used.
According to the Urasenke school, fukusa (a small silk wrapper) used by women in a tea ceremony is basically a scarlet-colored plain cloth, but patterned cloth may also be used.
According to the Urasenke school, fukusa (a small silk wrapper) used by women in a tea ceremony is basically a scarlet-colored plain cloth, but patterned cloth may also be used.

sen.j: 表千家では女性の袱紗（ふくさ）は朱無地である。
sen.e: According to Omote-Senke school, fukusa (small silk wrapper) to be used by women in a tea ceremony is shumuji cloth (vermillion colored plain cloth.)
According to the Omote-Senke school, fukusa (small silk wrapper) used by women in a tea ceremony is shumuji cloth (vermillion colored plain cloth.)
According to the Omote-Senke school, fukusa (small silk wrapper) used by women in a tea ceremony is shumuji cloth (vermillion colored plain cloth.)

sen.j: 三千家の中で裏千家の流儀を特徴づけるのは11代玄々斎以来特に顕著な「積極性」である。
sen.e: Among Sansenke schools (three Senke schools), Urasenke school has been featured by its particularly prominent "positiveness" since the generation of Gengensai, the 11th head of the school.
Among the three Sansenke schools, the Urasenke school has been featured by its particularly prominent "positive attitude" since the generation of Gengensai, the 11th head of the school.
Among the three Sansenke schools, the Urasenke school has been featured by its particularly prominent "positive attitude" since the generation of Gengensai, the eleventh headmaster of the school.

sen.j: 玄々斎による茶箱点・立礼式や、13代円能斎による盆略点に代表されるように、新しい点前を作ることに対して他の二家より積極的である。
sen.e: Urasenke school has kept more positive attitude than the other two Senke schools in creating new temae (tea serving manners/methods), as being represented by chabakodate (a tea serving method using tea chests) and ryureishiki (a style of tea ceremony using chairs to sit on), both invented by Gengensai, and bonryaku-date (bonryaku-type service) established by Ennosai, 13th head of the school.

Urasenke school has kept more positive attitude than the other two Senke schools in creating new temae (tea serving manners/methods), as being represented by chabakodate (a tea serving method using tea chests) and ryureishiki (a style of tea ceremony using chairs to sit on), both invented by Gengensai, and bonryaku-date (bonryaku-type service) established by Ennosai, 13th head of the school.

The Urasenke school has kept a more positive attitude than the other two Senke schools in creating new temae (tea serving manners/methods), as being represented by chabakodate (a tea serving method using tea chests) and ryureishiki (a style of tea ceremony using chairs to sit on), both invented by Gengensai, and bonryaku-date (bonryaku-type service) established by Ennosai, thirteenth head of the school.
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。 “Urasenke school has kept more”=> “The Urasenke school has kept a more ”

sen.j: 立礼や盆略はその後三千家やそれ以外の流派にも形を変えながら受容されているが、こうした積極性は伝統的な流派においては珍しい。
sen.e: Although these ryurei and bonryaku styles of the tea ceremony became later accepted by all sansenke schools and other schools, taking different forms, such positive attitudes as of Urasenke are rarely taken by other traditional schools.

Although the ryurei and bonryaku styles of tea ceremony later became accepted by all sansenke and other schools, in different forms, such a positive proggressive attitude characteristic of Urasenke is rarely seen among other traditional schools.

Although the ryurei and bonryaku styles of tea ceremony later became accepted by all sansenke and other schools, in different forms, such a positive progressive attitude characteristic of Urasenke is rarely seen among other traditional schools.

sen.j: もう一点、侘びを尊ぶ三千家の中にあって、比較的華やかな方向性を持っていることが挙げられる。
sen.e: As another feature of Urasenke, it tends to pursue brilliance and gorgeousness among Sansenke schools which basically respect austere refinement.
Another feature of Urasenke is that it tends to pursue brilliance and beauty, which is distinctive among the Sansenke schools that basically respect a more austere refinement.
Another feature of Urasenke is that it tends to pursue brilliance and beauty, which is distinctive among the Sansenke schools that basically respect a more austere refinement.

sen.j: 好み物の棚の種類が非常に多かったり、茶箱の色紙点のように彩り豊かな点前が好まれたりしている。
sen.e: For example, it offers considerably many kinds of shelves for preference, and it favors such colorful temae (a serving manner) like shikishi-date (a tea serving manner/method using colored paper) for chabako (a tea chest).

For example, it offers considerably more types of shelves for preference, and it favors such colorful temae (serving manner) like shikishi-date (a tea serving manner/method using colored paper) for chabako (a tea chest).

For example, it offers considerably more types of shelves for preference, and it favors such colorful temae (serving manner) like shikishi-date (a tea serving manner/method using colored paper) for chabako (a tea chest).

sen.j: 許状
sen.e: Kyojo (admission letter)
Kyojo (admission letter)
Kyojo (admission letter)

sen.j: 「許状」は、稽古することを許可する趣旨の書面であり、実力認定の意味合いが強い「免状」「免許」「段位」などとは性格が異なる。
sen.e: The term "kyojo (admission letter)" means a letter of admission to receive lessons of the tea ceremony, which is different in its nature from menjo (diploma), menkyo (license), dan-i (qualification of rank) and others that imply accreditation or authorization of member's capability.

The term "kyojo (admission letter)" means a letter of admission to attend the tea ceremony lessons, which is different in nature from menjo (diploma), menkyo (license), dan-i (qualification of rank) and others that imply accreditation or authorization of a member's capability.

The term "kyojo (admission letter)" means a letter of admission to attend the tea ceremony lessons, which is different in nature from menjo (diploma), menkyo (license), dan-i (qualification of rank) and others that imply accreditation or authorization of a member's capability.

sen.j: 裏千家ではさらに平成12年（2000年）から「許状」と対応した「資格」制度を設けている。
sen.e: Since 2000, Urasenke school has established a qualification system which is compatible with its kyojo (admission letter) system.
Since 2000, Urasenke school have established a qualification system which is compatible with its kyojo (admission letter) system.
Since 2000, Urasenke school has established a qualification system which is compatible with its kyojo (admission letter) system.
sen.cmt: 裏千家は「ひとつの」流派であるので、“have”より“has”が適切。両方可能だが、全体を通して統一が必要。

sen.j: これは従来「初伝」「中伝」などと称していたものを改定したもので、履歴書の資格欄に書いてわかりやすいようにという学習者の便宜を目的としたものである。
sen.e: This qualification system is a revision of conventional system including so called shoden (first degree), chuden (middle-class degree) and others, so that each learner may prepare his/her personal resume with clearly understandable description of the qualification.

This qualification system is a revision of the conventional system including the so called shoden (first degree), chuden (middle-class degree) and others, so that each student may prepare his/her personal resume with a clearly understandable description of the qualification.

This qualification system is a revision of the conventional system including the so called shoden (first degree), chuden (middle-class degree) and others, so that each student may prepare his/her personal resume with a clearly understandable description of the qualification.

sen.j: 資格は対応する許状を全て取得すると得られる。
sen.e: Qualifications may be given to any learner when he/she earns all corresponding kyojo (admission letters.)
Qualifications may be given to any learner when he/she earns all corresponding kyojo (admission letters.)
Qualifications may be given to any learner when he/she earns all corresponding kyojo (admission letters.)

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 成立から幕末まで
sen.e: From Establishment of School to the End of Edo Era
From the Establishment of the School to the End of the Edo Era
From the Establishment of the School to the End of the Edo Era

sen.j: 千家3代宗旦は、不審菴を三男江岑宗左に譲り、敷地内に新たに茶室を建てて隠居し、四男仙叟宗室と共に移り住んだ。
sen.e: The 3rd head of Senke school, Sotan, had passed Fushin-an arbour on to his 3rd son, Sosa KOSHIN, and moved to newly built tea arbours on the same premise to spend his retirement life together with his 4th son, Soshitsu Senso.

The 3rd head of Senke school, Sotan, had passed Fushin-an arbour on to his 3rd son, Sosa KOSHIN, and moved to newly built tea arbours on the same premise to spend his retirement together with his 4th son, Soshitsu Senso.

The 3rd head of Senke school, Sotan, had passed Fushin-an house on to his 3rd son, Sosa KOSHIN, and moved to newly built tea-ceremony house on the same premise to spend his retirement together with his 4th son, Soshitsu Senso.

sen.j: このときの茶室は今日庵（一畳台目）、利休四畳半を再現した又隠、寒雲亭（八畳）であり、これらがすべて宗室に譲られたことにより裏千家が成立する。
sen.e: The arbours ceded to Sotan were Konnichi-an with ichijo-daime (one and three third tatami mats), Yuin or reproduction of Rikyu yojohan (Rikyu's tea room with four and half tatami mats) and Kan-untei with eight tatami mats, all of which have contributed to the establishment of Urasenke shool.

The arbours ceded to Sotan were Konnichi-an with ichijo-daime (one and three third tatami mats), Yuin or reproduction of Rikyu yojohan (Rikyu's tea room with four and half tatami mats) and Kan-untei with eight tatami mats, all of which have contributed to the establishment of the Urasenke shool.
sen.cmt: One and three thirds… is not understood… three thirds = 1, please clarify
sen.e: The tea-ceremony house ceded to Sotan were Konnichi-an with ichijo-daime (one and three third tatami mats), Yuin or reproduction of Rikyu yojohan (Rikyu's tea room with four and half tatami mats) and Kan-untei with eight tatami mats, all of which have contributed to the establishment of the Urasenke school.
sen.cmt: arbour→tea-ceremony houseとしました。 Schoolのスペル。

sen.j: 4代仙叟宗室は寛永19年（1642年）に前田氏の当時すでに隠居であった前田利常に仕官し、二百石と小松城三の丸の屋敷を与えられた。
sen.e: In 1642, Soshitsu SENSO, the 4th head of Urasenke school, was retained by already retired Toshitsune MAEDA of the Maeda clan, and was given 200 koku salary with a residence at San-no-maru in Komatsu-jo castle.

In 1642, Soshitsu SENSO, the 4th head of the Urasenke school, was retained by already retired Toshitsune MAEDA of the Maeda clan, and was given a 200 koku salary with a residence at San-no-maru in Komatsu-jo castle.

In 1642, Soshitsu SENSO, the 4th head of the Urasenke school, was retained by the already retired Toshitsune MAEDA of the Maeda clan, and was given a 200 koku salary with a residence at San-no-maru in Komatsu-jo castle.
sen.cmt: 文法。定冠詞必要。“already retired”=>”the already retired”

sen.j: 万治元年（1658年）に前田利常と元伯宗旦が相次いで没すると、裏千家の4代を継承し、寛文11年（1671年）に前田綱紀に茶堂として仕官して百五十石と金沢城下の味噌蔵町の屋敷を与えられた。
sen.e: When Toshitsune MAEDA and Sotan GEMPAKU died in 1658, Soshitsu SENSO succeeded Urasenke school to become its 4h head, and in 1671 when he was retained by Tsunanori MAEDA as a tea server, he was given 150 koku salary and a residence at Misogura-cho in Kanazawa-jo castle town.

When Toshitsune MAEDA and Sotan GEMPAKU died in 1658, Soshitsu SENSO succeeded the Urasenke school to become its 4h head, and in 1671 when he was retained by Tsunanori MAEDA as a tea server, he was given a 150 koku salary and a residence at Misogura-cho in Kanazawa-jo castle town.

When Toshitsune MAEDA and Sotan GEMPAKU died in 1658, Soshitsu SENSO succeeded the Urasenke school to become its 4th head, and in 1671 when he was retained by Tsunanori MAEDA as a tea server, he was given a 150 koku salary and a residence at Misogura-cho in Kanazawa-jo castle town.

sen.j: 以後、元禄元年（1688年）までは金沢と京都とを往復しながら精力的に活動し、元禄10年（1697年）に没した。
sen.e: Afterwards, Soshitsu SENSO maintained his energetic activities traveling back and forth between Kanazawa and Kyoto until 1688, and died in 1697.
Afterwards, Soshitsu SENSO maintained his energetic activities traveling back and forth between Kanazawa and Kyoto until 1688, and died in 1697.
Afterwards, Soshitsu SENSO maintained his energetic activities traveling back and forth between Kanazawa and Kyoto until 1688, and died in 1697.

sen.j: 仙叟宗室の没後すぐに5代常叟宗室が加賀藩に仕官したが、ほどなく辞して伊予松山藩久松氏に仕官する。
sen.e: Immediately after the death of Soshitsu Senso, his successor and the 5th head of the school, Soshitsu JOSO, was retained by Kaga domain but soon resigned from it to serve the Hisamatsu clan of Iyo-Matsuyama domain.

Immediately after the death of Soshitsu Senso, his successor and the 5th head of the school, Soshitsu JOSO, was retained by Kaga domain but soon resigned to serve the Hisamatsu clan of Iyo-Matsuyama domain.

Immediately after the death of Soshitsu Senso, his successor and the 5th head of the school, Soshitsu JOSO, was retained by Kaga domain but soon resigned to serve the Hisamatsu clan of Iyo-Matsuyama domain.

sen.j: 以降、幕末に至るまで久松家に仕官しながら前田家とも交流を続けることになる。
sen.e: From then until the end of Edo era, Soshitsu JOSO continued his services to his retainer the Hisamatsu family, keeping at the same time constant contact with the Maeda family, too.
From then until the end of the Edo era, Soshitsu JOSO continued his services to his retainer, the Hisamatsu family, also keeping, at the same time, constant contact with the Maeda family.
From then until the end of the Edo era, Soshitsu JOSO continued his services to his retainer, the Hisamatsu family, also keeping, at the same time, constant contact with the Maeda family.

sen.j: その後8代一燈宗室のときに徳島藩蜂須賀氏にも出向いている。
sen.e: Later on, Soshitsu (the head of the Urasenke Tradition of Tea) Itto YUGENSAI, the 8th head of the Urasenke school, has visited the Hachisuka clan of Tokushima domain.
Later on, Soshitsu (the head of the Urasenke Tradition of Tea) Itto YUGENSAI, the 8th head of the Urasenke school, visited the Hachisuka clan of Tokushima domain.
Later on, Soshitsu (the head of the Urasenke Tradition of Tea) Itto YUGENSAI, the 8th head of the Urasenke school, visited the Hachisuka clan of Tokushima domain.

sen.j: 8代又玄斎一燈は兄の表千家7代如心斎と共に千家の中興とされる。
sen.e: Soshitsu Itto YUGENSAI, the 8th head of the Urasenke school, and his elder brother Joshinsai, the 7th head of the Omote Senke school, are both regarded as major contributors to the restoration of Senke schools.

Soshitsu Itto YUGENSAI, the 8th head of the Urasenke school, and his elder brother Joshinsai, the 7th head of the Omote Senke school, are both regarded as major contributors to the restoration of Senke schools.

Soshitsu Itto YUGENSAI, the 8th head of the Urasenke school, and his elder brother Joshinsai, the 7th head of the Omote Senke school, are both regarded as major contributors to the restoration of Senke schools.

sen.j: 彼らは茶の湯が大衆化していく中で、新たな稽古の方法として七事式を制定するなどして千家の茶道を広めることに成功した。
sen.e: In the circumstances that the art of the tea ceremony became increasingly popularized, they could successfully disseminate Senke's tea ceremony by instituting new methods to practice it, called shichijishiki (seven types of methods to practice the tea ceremony.)

As the art of tea ceremony became increasingly popularized, they could successfully disseminate Senke's tea ceremony by instituting new methods for practicing it, called shichijishiki (seven types of methods to practice the tea ceremony.)

As the art of tea ceremony became increasingly popularized, they could successfully disseminate Senke's tea ceremony by instituting new methods for practicing it, called shichijishiki (seven types of methods to practice the tea ceremony.)

sen.j: 今日、三千家が茶道の代表格として語られるのは、流祖である千利休の高名だけでなく、この時期に広く各地の町人富裕層に普及したことも大きな要因となっている。
sen.e: Today, Sansenke (three Senke schools) are widely referred to as the representatives of the tea ceremony, the main reasons of which is not only the fame of their originator, Sen no Rikyu, but also the fact that Sansenke's methods were commonly accepted among rich class town people every where in Japan at that time.

Today, the three Senke schools are widely referred to as the representatives of tea ceremony, the main reasons are not only the fame of their originator, Sen no Rikyu, but also the fact that Sansenke's methods were commonly accepted among the rich class town people every where in Japan during that time.

Today, the three Senke schools are widely referred to as the representatives of tea ceremony, the main reasons are not only the fame of their originator, Sen no Rikyu, but also the fact that Sansenke's methods were commonly accepted among the rich class town people every where in Japan during that time.

sen.j: 天明8年（1788年）正月晦日、京都で大火があり表裏両千家は完全に焼失している。
sen.e: On the eve of new year of 1788, there was a massive fire in Kyoto, which burned out entire premises of Omote Senke and Urasenke.
On new year's eve in 1788, there was a massive fire in Kyoto, which burned out the entire premises of Omote Senke and Urasenke.
On new year's eve in 1788, there was a massive fire in Kyoto, which burned out the entire premises of Omote Senke and Urasenke.

sen.j: このとき伝来の道具などは大徳寺に持ち出すことができたが、数々の茶室はすべて焼失してしまった。
sen.e: Then, traditional gears and instruments could be carried out of the fire to Daitoku-ji temple, but various tea arbours were completely burned to the ground.
Then, traditional equipment and instruments could be carried out of the fire to Daitoku-ji temple, but various tea arbours were completely burned to the ground.
Then, traditional equipment and instruments could be carried out of the fire to Daitoku-ji temple, but various tea-ceremony houses were completely burned to the ground.

sen.j: ほとんどは9代不見斎石翁によって翌年までに再建されている。
sen.e: It was Seiko FUKENSAI, the 9th head of the school, who has reconstructed almost all of the burned premises.
It was Seiko FUKENSAI, the 9th head of the school, who has reconstructed almost all of the burned premises.
It was Sekio FUKENSAI, the 9th head of the school, who reconstructed almost all of the burned premises.
sen.cmt: 文法。 現状の “has” では不見斎石翁がまだ存命の印象。→削除。

sen.j: 幕末・明治以後
sen.e: After End of Edo Era and Beginning of Meiji
After End of Edo Era and Beginning of Meiji
After End of Edo Era and Beginning of Meiji

sen.j: 11代玄々斎精中は10代認得斎柏叟の女婿として10歳のときに奥殿藩松平家から養子に入った人である。
sen.e: Seichu GENGENSAI, the 11th head of Urasenke school, was a person who had been adopted at the age of ten from Matsudaira family of Okutono domain to become a husband of a daughter of Hakuso NINTOKUSAI, the 10th head of the school.

Seichu GENGENSAI, the 11th head of the Urasenke school, was adopted at the age of ten from the Matsudaira family of the Okutono domain to become a husband of the daughter of Hakuso NINTOKUSAI, the 10th head of the school.

Seichu GENGENSAI, the eleventh head of the Urasenke school, was adopted at the age of ten from the Matsudaira family of the Okutono domain to become a husband of the daughter of Hakuso NINTOKUSAI, the tenth head of the school.

sen.j: それまでの歴代が禅的消極的であったのに対し、茶道以外にも華道、香道、謡曲などに通じていて、茶箱点や立礼式の創始、和巾点の復興など、明朗で積極的な人であった。
sen.e: In contrast with previous heads of the school, who had taken negative attitude in a Zen manner, Seichu GENGENSAI was a cheerful and active person with expertise in not only the tea ceremony but also the flower arrangement, the traditional incense-smelling ceremony and the Noh songs, who created such new methods of the tea ceremony as chabakodate (a tea serving method using a tea chest) and ryureishiki (a style of tea ceremony using chairs to sit on) and also restored wakindate (a tea serving method using wakin or traditional Japanese cloth.)

In contrast with previous heads of the school, who had such a negative attitude in a Zen manner, Seichu GENGENSAI was a cheerful and active person with expertise in not only the tea ceremony but also flower arrangement, the traditional incense-smelling ceremony and Noh songs, who created such new methods of tea ceremony as chabakodate (a tea serving method using a tea chest) and ryureishiki (a style of tea ceremony using chairs to sit on) and also restored wakindate (a tea serving method using wakin or traditional Japanese cloth.)

In contrast with previous heads of the school, who had had a rather passive Zen-style attitude, Seichu GENGENSAI was a cheerful and active person with expertise in not only the tea ceremony but also flower arrangement, the traditional incense-smelling ceremony and Noh songs, who created such new methods of tea ceremony as chabakodate (a tea serving method using a tea chest) and ryureishiki (a style of tea ceremony using chairs to sit on) and also restored wakindate (a tea serving method using wakin or traditional Japanese cloth.)
sen.cmt: 表現スタイルが不適切。 ”the school, who had such a negative attitude in a Zen manner,”→”the school, who had had a rather passive Zen-style attitude,”

sen.j: 立礼式は明治5年（1872年）の博覧会に際して外国人を迎えるための創案であり、また同じ年に『茶道の源意』を著して茶道は遊芸とする風潮を批判するなど、幕末から明治の変動の時代に合わせた茶道の近代化の先駆として評価されている。
sen.e: He is appraised as a pioneer to modernize the tea ceremony in line with the changing world from the end of Edo era to Meiji era, being credited for his invention of ryureishiki style tea ceremony which was specially arranged to welcome foreign visitors to the exhibition held in 1872, and also for his criticism against general trend to consider the tea ceremony as art for amusement, as written in his book "Sado no Gen-i (literally, Root Meaning of the Tea Ceremony.)"

He is appraised as a pioneer for modernizing the tea ceremony in step with a changing world from the end of the Edo era to the Meiji era, being credited for his innovative ryureishiki style tea ceremony which was specially arranged to welcome foreign visitors to the exhibition held in 1872, and also for his criticism against the general trend to consider tea ceremony as art for amusement, as written in his book "Sado no Gen-i (literally, Root Meaning of the Tea Ceremony.)"

He is appraised as a pioneer for modernizing the tea ceremony in step with a changing world from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period, being credited for his innovative ryureishiki style tea ceremony which was specially arranged to welcome foreign visitors to the exhibition held in 1872, and also for his criticism against the general trend to consider tea ceremony as art for amusement, as written in his book "Sado no Gen-i (literally, Root Meaning of the Tea Ceremony.)"

sen.j: 明治に入り角倉家から養子に迎えた12代又玅斎直叟の放蕩によって一旦は破産するものの、その後13代円能斎鉄中の普及活動によって復興する。
sen.e: Due to dissipation by Jikisho YUMYOSAI, who was an adoptee from the Suminokura family and became the 12th head of Urasenke school, this school had once become bankrupt in Meiji era, but later restored thanks to dissemination activities of Tetchu ENNOSAI, the 13th head of the school.

Due to dissipation by Jikisho YUMYOSAI, who was an adoptee from the Suminokura family and became the 12th head of Urasenke school, this school had once become bankrupt during the Meiji era, but later restored thanks to dissemination activities of Tetchu ENNOSAI, the 13th head of the school.

Due to dissipation by Jikisho YUMYOSAI, who was an adoptee from the Suminokura family and became the twelfth head of Urasenke school, this school had once become bankrupt during the Meiji era, but was later restored thanks to the dissemination activities of Tetchu ENNOSAI, the thirteenth head of the school.
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。 “ but later restored thanks to dissemination activities”=> “but was later restored thanks to the dissemination activities ”

sen.j: 円能斎は明治29年まで6年にわたって東京に居を移して協力者を求め、京都に戻ってからも教本の出版や機関誌 「今日庵月報」などの発行を通して一般への茶道普及に尽力した。
sen.e: Ennosai, who had moved his residence to Tokyo to live there for six years from 1896 in quest of collaborators, returned to Kyoto and exerted himself for popularization of Urasenke's tea ceremony through publication of instructional books and journals of "Konnichi-an Geppo (literally, monthly journal of Konnichi-an arbour.)

Ennosai, who had moved his residence to Tokyo to live for six years from 1896 in quest of collaborators, returned to Kyoto and exerted himself for the popularization of Urasenke's tea ceremony through the publication of instructional books and journals of "Konnichi-an Geppo (literally, monthly journal of Konnichi-an arbour.)

Ennosai, who had moved his residence to Tokyo to live for six years up until 1896 in quest of collaborators, returned to Kyoto and exerted himself for the popularization of Urasenke's tea ceremony through the publication of instructional books and journals of "Konnichi-an Geppo (literally, monthly journal of Konnichi-an.)
sen.cmt: 「明治29年まで」を「up until 1896」としました。

sen.j: また女学校教育の中に茶道を取り入れ、かつ教授方針の一致をはかる講習会を催すなど裏千家茶道の組織化にも力を注いだ。
sen.e: He also tried best to systemize Urasenke's tea ceremony course by introducing it into curriculums of girls' schools and holding lectures in order to unify its teaching policies.
He also tried his best to systemize Urasenke's tea ceremony course by introducing it into curriculums of girls' schools and holding lectures in order to unify its teaching policies.
He also tried his best to systemize Urasenke's tea ceremony course by introducing it into curriculums of girls' schools and holding lectures in order to unify its teaching policies.

sen.j: その他、三友式の創始や、流し点や大円点の復興などの功績がある。
sen.e: In addition, he has contributed to creation of Sanyu-shiki and restoration of Nagashi-tate and Daien-tate.
sen.cmt: 三友式→Sanyu-shiki[定訳不明]流し点→Nagashi-tate[定訳不明]大円点→Daien-tate[定訳不明]
sen.e: In addition, he has contributed to the creation of Sanyu-shiki and the restoration of Nagashi-tate and Daien-tate.
In addition, he has contributed to the creation of Sanyu-shiki and the restoration of Nagashi-tate and Daien-tate.

sen.j: 戦後になって14代淡々斎碩叟が茶道の学校教育への導入を働きかけた結果、学校のクラブ活動で教えられる茶道の大半は裏千家となっている。
sen.e: After the world war II, Sekiso TANTANSAI, the 14th head of the Urasenke school has worked on introduction of a tea ceremony course into curriculums of school education, which led to make Urasenke's method dominant at any school's club activities of the tea ceremony

After world war II, Sekiso TANTANSAI, the 14th head of the Urasenke school worked on introducing a tea ceremony course into school education curriculums, which led to making Urasenke's method dominant at all school club activities concerning tea ceremony

After World War II, Sekiso TANTANSAI, the fourteenth head of the Urasenke school worked on introducing a tea ceremony course into school education curriculums, which led to making Urasenke's method dominant at all school club activities concerning tea ceremony.
sen.cmt: 頭文字を大文字にする必要。 “world war II” => “World War II” - 名詞であるため。

sen.j: 淡々斎はまた各地の寺院・神社にて献茶・供茶を行ったり、海外への普及に取り組んだりと、茶道振興に功が大きい。
sen.e: Tantansai is also credited with promotion of the tea ceremony through tea offerings at shrines and temples everywhere in Japan as well as his engagement in its dissemination activities abroad.
Tantansai is also credited with promoting the tea ceremony through tea offerings at shrines and temples everywhere in Japan as well as his engaging in its dissemination activities abroad.
Tantansai is also credited with promoting the tea ceremony through tea offerings at shrines and temples everywhere in Japan as well as engaging in its dissemination activities abroad.

sen.j: 全国統一の同門組織として社団法人淡交会を結成し、また家元を財団法人化するなど、裏千家茶道の組織化も引き続き行われ、流派別の茶道人口としては最大規模を誇るようになった。
sen.e: He has continued his efforts to systemize organization of Urasenke's tea ceremony by setting up a national organization of fellow members, named Tanko-kai, and also by obtaining corporate status for the head of the school and his family, so that Urasenke is now proud of being the largest scale school among many tea ceremony schools.

He continued his efforts to systemize organization of Urasenke's tea ceremony by setting up a national organization of fellow members, named Tanko-kai, and also by obtaining corporate status for the head of the school and his family, so Urasenke is now proud of being the largest scale school among many tea ceremony schools.

He continued his efforts to systemize organization of Urasenke's tea ceremony by setting up a national organization of fellow members, named Tanko-kai, and also by obtaining corporate status for the head of the school and his family, so Urasenke is now proud of being the largest scale school among many tea ceremony schools.

sen.j: こうした普及・組織化の活動は15代鵬雲斎汎叟にも引き継がれ、特に海外普及に力を注がれた。
sen.e: Such activities of dissemination and systemization were succeeded by Hoso HOUNSAI, the 15th head of Urasenke school, who has extended his efforts particularly for promotion abroad.
Such activities for dissemination and systemization were succeeded by Hoso HOUNSAI, the 15th head of the Urasenke school, who has applied his efforts, particularly, for promotion abroad.
Such activities for dissemination and systemization were continued by Hoso HOUNSAI, the fifteenth head of the Urasenke school, who has applied his efforts, in particular, to promotion abroad.
sen.cmt: “ were succeeded by ”=>” were continued by ” “ particularly, for promotion abroad”=> “in particular, to promotion abroad”

sen.j: 鵬雲斎はまた社団法人日本青年会議所会頭を務めた。
sen.e: Hounsai was a chairman at Junior Chamber International Japan.
Hounsai was a chairman at the Junior Chamber International Japan.
Hounsai was a chairman at the Junior Chamber International Japan.

sen.j: 歴代家元
sen.e: Consecutive Heads of Senke Schools
Consecutive Heads of Senke Schools
Consecutive Heads of Senke Schools

sen.j: 千利休の没後、傍系の少庵（後妻の連子）の後を継いだ千宗旦が京都に屋敷を構え、次男 宗守・三男 宗左・四男 宗室にそれぞれ武者小路千家・表千家・裏千家を興させたのが三千家の始まりであるが、各家ともに家元は利休を初代として数える。
sen.e: After Sen no Rikyu died, Sen no Soutan, successor of collateral son of Sen no Rikyu, Shouan (a son of previous marrage of the second wife of Rikyu,) fixed his residence in Kyoto, and induced his three sons, namely Sosyu, Sosa and Soshitsu, establish three schools of the tea ceremony, namely Mushanokoji Senke, Omote Senke and Urasenke, respectively; which is the story to tell the start of Sansenke (three Senke schools) but each of the schools claims that their original head was Sen no Rikyu.

After Sen no Rikyu died, Sen no Soutan, successor of collateral son of Sen no Rikyu, Shouan (son of a previous marrage of the second wife of Rikyu,) fixed his residence in Kyoto, and induced his three sons, namely Sosyu, Sosa and Soshitsu,to establish three schools of tea ceremony, namely Mushanokoji Senke, Omote Senke, and Urasenke, respectively; which is the story that tells how Sansenke started (three Senke schools), but each of the schools claims that their original head was Sen no Rikyu.

After Sen no Rikyu died, Sen no Soutan, successor of collateral son of Sen no Rikyu, Shouan (son of a previous marriage of the second wife of Rikyu,) fixed his residence in Kyoto, and induced his three sons, namely Sosyu, his second son, Sosa, his third son, and Soshitsu, his forth son, to establish three schools of tea ceremony, namely Mushanokoji Senke, Omote Senke, and Urasenke, respectively; which is the story that tells how Sansenke started (three Senke schools), but each of the schools claims that their original head was Sen no Rikyu.

sen.j: 裏千家の家元は四代である仙叟の諱「宗室」を受け継いでいるが、表千家・武者小路千家とは異なり初期は襲名をしていなかったらしく、また家元後嗣（若宗匠）が特定の名を名乗る伝統もない。
sen.e: Consecutive heads of Urasenke school have succeeded the name "Soshitsu" which was the real personal name of Senso, the 4th head of the school, but it seems that the school in its early period had no traditon for the current head to succeed the name of his predecessor nor for the koshi (successor) of current head (called Wakasosho) to anounce special name.

Consecutive heads of Urasenke school have succeeded the name "Soshitsu" which was the real personal name of Senso, the 4th head of the school, but it seems that the school during its early period didn't have the traditon for the current head to succeed the name of his predecessor nor for the koshi (successor) of current head (called Wakasosho) to anounce a special name.

Consecutive heads of the Ura-senke school have inherited the name "Soshitsu," which was the real personal name of Senso the 4th head of the school, but unlike the Omote-senke and Mushanokoji-senke schools, this school doesn't seem to have had a tradition of the current head inheriting the name of his predecessor during its early years or of the Wakasosho (the koshi, or successor, to the current head) assuming a special name.
sen.cmt: traditon→tradition 「表千家・武者小路千家とは異なり」を訳出しました。

sen.j: 従来、十四世、十五世のように称していたが、最近は十五代、十六代のように表記されている。
sen.e: Conventionally, generations of heads of the school have been referred to as, for example, 14-sei (14th) and 15-sei (15th), but lately, they are described as 14-dai (14th) and 15-dai (15th.)
Conventionally, generations of the heads of the school have been referred to as; 14-sei (14th) and 15-sei (15th), but lately, they are described as 14-dai (14th) and 15-dai (15th.)

Conventionally, generations of the heads of the school have been referred to as; 14-sei (fourteenth) and 15-sei (fifteenth), but lately, they are described as 15-dai (fifteenth) and 16-dai (sixteenth.)
sen.cmt: 序数をスペルアウト,数字訂正

sen.j: 裏千家歴代
sen.e: Consecutive Heads of Urasenke School
Consecutive Heads of the Urasenke School
Consecutive Heads of the Urasenke School
